Act2Scene3.speaker: Macduff
Act2Scene3.text: Is thy master stirring?

Act2Scene3.speaker: Lennox
Act2Scene3.text: Good morrow, noble sir.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macbeth
Act2Scene3.text: Good morrow, both.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macduff
Act2Scene3.text: Is the King stirring, worthy thane?

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macbeth
Act2Scene3.text: Not yet.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macduff
Act2Scene3.text: He did command me to call timely on him. I have almost slipped the hour.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macbeth
Act2Scene3.text: I’ll bring you to him.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macduff
Act2Scene3.text: I know this is a joyful trouble to you, But yet ’tis one.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macbeth
Act2Scene3.text: The labor we delight in physics pain. This is the door.
Act2Scene3.translation: The work we enjoy doing relieves our pain. This is the door.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macduff
Act2Scene3.text: I’ll make so bold to call, For ’tis my limited service.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Lennox
Act2Scene3.text: Goes the King hence today?

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macbeth
Act2Scene3.text: He does. He did appoint so.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Lennox
Act2Scene3.text: The night has been unruly.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macbeth
Act2Scene3.text: ’Twas a rough night.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Lennox
Act2Scene3.text: My young remembrance cannot parallel A fellow to it.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macduff
Act2Scene3.text: O horror, horror, horror! Tongue nor heart cannot conceive nor name thee!

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macbeth and Lennox
Act2Scene3.text: What’s the matter?

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macduff
Act2Scene3.text: Confusion now hath made his masterpiece. Most sacrilegious murder hath broke ope The Lord’s anointed temple and stole thence The life o’ th’ building.
Act2Scene3.translation: Chaos has taken over. A horrible murder has broken open God's temple and have stole the life from it.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macbeth
Act2Scene3.text: What is ’t you say? The life?

Act2Scene3.speaker: Lennox
Act2Scene3.text: Mean you his Majesty?

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macduff
Act2Scene3.text: Approach the chamber. Do not bid me speak. See and then speak yourselves.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macduff
Act2Scene3.text: Awake, awake! Ring the alarum bell.—Murder and treason! Banquo and Donalbain, Malcolm, awake!—Ring the bell.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act2Scene3.text: What’s the business, That such a hideous trumpet calls to parley The sleepers of the house? Speak, speak!

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macduff
Act2Scene3.text: O gentle lady, ’Tis not for you to hear what I can speak.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macduff
Act2Scene3.text: O Banquo, Banquo, Our royal master’s murdered.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act2Scene3.text: Woe, alas! What, in our house?

Act2Scene3.speaker: Banquo
Act2Scene3.text: Too cruel anywhere.— Dear Duff, I prithee, contradict thyself And say it is not so.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macbeth
Act2Scene3.text: Had I but died an hour before this chance, I had lived a blessèd time; for from this instant There’s nothing serious in mortality.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Donalbain
Act2Scene3.text: What is amiss?

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macbeth
Act2Scene3.text: You are, and do not know ’t. The spring, the head, the fountain of your blood Is stopped; the very source of it is stopped.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macduff
Act2Scene3.text: Your royal father’s murdered.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Malcolm
Act2Scene3.text: O, by whom?

Act2Scene3.speaker: Lennox
Act2Scene3.text: Those of his chamber, as it seemed, had done ’t. Their hands and faces were all badged with blood. So were their daggers, which unwiped we found Upon their pillows. They stared and were distracted. No man’s life was to be trusted with them.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macbeth
Act2Scene3.text: O, yet I do repent me of my fury, That I did kill them.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macduff
Act2Scene3.text: Wherefore did you so?

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macbeth
Act2Scene3.text: Who can be wise, amazed, temp’rate, and furious, Loyal, and neutral, in a moment? No man.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macbeth
Act2Scene3.text: Th’ expedition of my violent love o    utrun the pauser, reason. Here lay Duncan, His silver skin laced with his golden blood; there the murderers, Steeped in the colors of their trade, their daggers Unmannerly breeched with gore. Who could refrain That had a heart to love, and in that heart Courage to make ’s love known?

Act2Scene3.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act2Scene3.text: Help me hence, ho!

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macduff
Act2Scene3.text: Look to the lady.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Malcolm
Act2Scene3.text: Why do we hold our tongues, That most may claim this argument for ours?

Act2Scene3.speaker: Donalbain
Act2Scene3.text: What should be spoken here, where our fate, Hid in an auger hole, may rush and seize us? Let’s away. Our tears are not yet brewed.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Malcolm
Act2Scene3.text: Nor our strong sorrow upon the foot of motion.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Banquo
Act2Scene3.text: Look to the lady. And when we have our naked frailties hid, That suffer in exposure, let us meet And question this most bloody piece of work To know it further.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macduff
Act2Scene3.text: And so do I.

Act2Scene3.speaker: All
Act2Scene3.text: So all.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Macbeth
Act2Scene3.text: Let’s briefly put on manly readiness And meet i’ th’ hall together.

Act2Scene3.speaker: All
Act2Scene3.text: Well contented.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Malcolm
Act2Scene3.text: What will you do? Let’s not consort with them. I’ll to England.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Donalbain
Act2Scene3.text: To Ireland I. Our separated fortune Shall keep us both the safer.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Malcolm
Act2Scene3.text: This murderous shaft that’s shot Hath not yet lighted, and our safest way Is to avoid the aim.
Act2Scene3.translation: This murderous arrow that has been shot has not yet hit its target, and the safest way for us is to avoid the target.

Act2Scene3.speaker: Malcolm
Act2Scene3.text: Therefore to horse, And let us not be dainty of leave-taking But shift away.
